title-group.article-title: Headache Phenotype and the Psychosocial Burden of Cluster Headaches: An Analysis of Patients Prior to Hospitalization

contrib-group.aff: 1https://ror.org/01tvm6f46grid.412468.d0000 0004 0646 2097Department of Neurology, University Hospital Schleswig-Holstein, Campus, Kiel, Germany

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The specific headache phenotype, accompanying symptoms and psychological impact that lead to admission of patients with cluster headache are not yet known. The aim of this study was therefore to analyze the characteristics of patients who were admitted to a tertiary headache center in 2018, 2019 and 2020 due to cluster headache.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: A total of 207 patients with cluster headache were examined, who were admitted to the Kiel Headache Center, a tertiary headache center in Germany, in the years 2018, 2019, and 2020. A retrospective cohort study was conducted to analyze the phenotype and psychosocial impact of cluster headaches in a standardized manner. The data were collected based on information from the standardized Kiel Headache Questionnaire, the Migraine Disability Assessment (MIDAS) questionnaire, and the World Health Organization (WHO) Disability Assessment Schedule (WHODAS 2.0).

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Most of the patients had a chronic course of disease over many years, and 71.5% had had the disease for more than 5 years. Cluster headache attacks occurred in 98.6% of the patients, with strong to very strong pain intensity, and more than 78% of the patients experienced three or more attacks per day. Nighttime occurrence led to severe sleep disturbances with exhaustion, a lack of energy, and an inability to work. In 31.4% of the patients, persistent pain in the area also contributed to the inability to work. A total of 94.7% of the patients had a MIDAS score of grade 4. The analysis of the WHODAS 2.0 score revealed that 92.7% of the patients with cluster headaches experienced severe limitations in their health and functionality. These individuals were particularly severely affected by the accompanying psychological symptoms and the psychosocial impact of cluster headaches. The highly stressful complications of cluster headaches were particularly evident in the high frequency of suicidal ideation in more than 40% of the patients examined. Severe illness affected almost all areas of professional, social, and family life and caused a very high level of suffering.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: The results revealed a pronounced, severe symptom complex in patients with cluster headaches that went far beyond the purely diagnostic criteria. The psychosocial impact of cluster headaches should be given close attention in the care of these patients.

custom-meta.meta-value: © Springer Healthcare Ltd., part of Springer Nature 2025

tr.td: Owing to the severe level of suffering and the associated complex comorbidity, patients who are severely affected by cluster headaches cannot always be adequately treated in an outpatient setting; in the case of treatment-resistant headache, inpatient treatment is required.
The headache phenotype, accompanying symptoms, complications and psychological impact that lead to admission in this patient group are not yet known.

bold.italic: What was learned from the study?

tr.td: The results revealed a pronounced, severe symptom complex in patients with cluster headaches that went far beyond the purely diagnostic criteria.

Most of the patients had a chronic course over many years, and 71.5% had already had the disease for more than 5 years. Cluster headache attacks occurred in 98.6% of the patients, with strong to very strong pain intensity, and more than 78% of the patients experienced three or more attacks per day.

Patients with cluster headaches were severely affected by the accompanying psychological symptoms and the psychosocial impact of cluster headache. The highly stressful effects of cluster headaches were particularly evident in the high frequency of suicidal ideation in more than 40% of the patients examined.
The psychosocial impact of the disease should therefore be given close attention in the care of patients with cluster headaches.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Cluster headache (CH) is a primary headache disorder diagnosed on the basis of the third edition of the International Classification of Headache Disorders (ICHD-3) criteria [1]. Cluster headache attacks (CHs) are characterized by severe, strictly unilateral pain in the orbital, supraorbital, temporal area or in any combination of these sites; CHs last 15–180 min and occur once every other day to eight times a day. During the most severe episodes, the pain is unbearably intense. CHs are associated with ipsilateral conjunctival injection, lacrimation, nasal congestion, rhinorrhea, forehead and facial sweating, miosis, and ptosis and/or eyelid edema with restlessness or agitation [1]. Attacks typically occur in clusters that last for weeks or months, known as cluster periods or bouts, which are followed by remission phases that usually span months or years. However, approximately 10–15% of patients experience chronic CH, characterized by the absence of these remission periods [1–7].

Unpredictable, often nocturnal CHs are among the most severe pain disorders in humans. This disorder has a serious impact not only on social life, relationships, and family life but also on professional activities and the ability to work. Comorbidities such as anxiety disorders, depression, and sleep disorders can also occur, which can greatly increase the level of suffering [8–12]. The onset of CHs most commonly occurs between the ages of 20 and 40 years [1, 2]. CHs can begin in childhood, adolescence, young adulthood, or even later in life [13, 14].

On average, it takes 8 years before the diagnosis of CH is made and adequate treatment is initiated [4, 15, 16]. Recent research suggests that the diagnostic delay for CHs has decreased. A systematic review by Buture et al. [15] revealed that patients with CHs frequently visit multiple healthcare providers and experience delays of 3–9 years before obtaining an accurate diagnosis. This review highlights that delays in diagnosing CHs remain a prevalent issue, with the time to diagnosis differing across countries. In contrast, the Danish Cluster Headache Survey [16] revealed a reduction in diagnostic delays over each decade studied, although atypical features of CHs were linked to extended delays in diagnosis. Enhancing medical education and increasing awareness of the condition are essential to avoid misdiagnosis and reduce diagnostic delays. Similarly, a multicenter registry study conducted in South Korea [17] demonstrated a steady improvement in diagnosis rates over time, underscoring the benefits of heightened awareness and revised diagnostic criteria. The data indicate that psychological comorbidities such as anxiety, depression and suicidality increase continuously with increasing delays in diagnosis. Further studies have shown that CHs are a risk factor for psychiatric comorbidities [10, 12, 18]. As a result, prolonged diagnostic delays may exacerbate the condition, particularly concerning psychiatric aspects [17, 18].

In Germany, headache patients are initially treated in general practice. If specialized treatment is needed, patients are referred to a neurologist. Specialists with an additional qualification in specialized pain therapy are available as an additional option. If sufficient therapy results cannot be achieved on an outpatient basis, admission for inpatient treatment is possible [19]. In 2022, 1049 men and 527 women with CHs were treated as inpatients in hospitals throughout Germany (ICD-10 code G44.0) [20]. Inpatient Multimodal Pain Therapy (MPT) in Germany, defined under OPS 8-918, is a structured, interdisciplinary treatment approach for patients suffering from chronic pain conditions that cannot be adequately managed with standard outpatient care. It integrates multiple therapeutic disciplines to address the biological, psychological, and social factors contributing to pain. It is a comprehensive, evidence-based approach aimed at providing effective relief for complex chronic pain conditions. It exemplifies a biopsychosocial model of care, ensuring patients receive individualized, interdisciplinary treatment tailored to their specific needs. OPS 8–918 serves as the coding standard for billing multimodal pain therapy within the German healthcare system. Proper documentation of the therapy's interdisciplinary nature, duration, and intensity is essential for reimbursement under statutory health insurance. For hospital admission for multimodal pain therapy, the requirements of the operation and procedure code OPS 8–918 must be met [21]. Multimodal pain therapy must be carried out by specialists in at least two disciplines, one of whom must come from the fields of psychiatry, psychosomatics or psychology-psychotherapy. Patients must have at least three of the following characteristics for admission:
Manifested or imminent impairment of quality of life and/or the ability to work
Failure of previous unimodal pain therapy, pain-related surgery or withdrawal treatment
Existing dependence on or the misuse of medication
Concomitant mental illness as a maintaining factor for pain
Serious concomitant somatic illness

These criteria generally describe the requirements for inpatient therapy for pain disorders. The specific headache phenotype, accompanying symptoms, and psychological impact that lead to admission of patients with CHs are not yet known. The aim of this study was therefore to analyze the characteristics of patients who were admitted to a tertiary headache center in 2018, 2019, and 2020 due to CHs.

sec.title: Design
sec.p: In this retrospective data analysis, the data of patients with a principal diagnosis of CH who were experiencing an active cluster period and were admitted to the tertiary headache center of the Kiel Migraine and Headache Centre in 2018, 2019, and 2020 for multimodal inpatient pain therapy were recorded. All patients included in this study provided written informed consent for the collection and analysis of their data. The study was conducted in accordance with the principles of the Declaration of Helsinki and approved by the ethics committee of the University of Kiel (D 626/20). Patient confidentiality and data protection were ensured throughout the study, and all data were anonymized prior to analysis.

The headache phenotypic data were collected via the standardized Kiel Headache Questionnaire [22] prior to hospitalization. To additionally record the impact of CHs, the Migraine Disability Assessment Score [23–26], the Beck Depression Inventory [27–34] and the World Health Organization Disability Assessment Schedule (WHODAS 2.0) [35–42] were used.

The Kiel Headache Questionnaire [22] is a standardized questionnaire that is designed to record headache phenotypes, comorbidities and impacts on psychosocial life. The paper‒pencil questionnaire is completed by patients before admission to the hospital to record their symptoms in advance and to check whether the admission criteria for the procedure code OPS 8–918 are met [21]. The questionnaire consists of detailed questions on the location, intensity, time course, frequency, character, accompanying symptoms and concomitant diseases of headache patients.

The Migraine Disability Assessment (MIDAS) is a validated questionnaire that was specifically developed to measure impairment in people with migraine in everyday life. It consists of five questions that document impairment at school or work, performance at home and participation in family, social, and leisure activities over the last 3 months by indicating the days affected. Disability is ultimately assessed via a point system: no or little impairment is given up to 5 points, minor impairment is given up to 10 points, moderate impairment is given up to 20 points, and severe impairment is given from 21 points onwards [23–26].

The Beck Depression Inventory II (BDI-II) is a validated psychological test that was developed as a short version to determine the severity of depressive symptoms [27–34]. It categorizes depressive symptoms into four severity levels based on the total score, which ranges from 0 to 63. A score between 0 and 13 indicates minimal depression, reflecting little to no depressive symptoms and is considered within the normal range of mood variability. A score of 14 to 19 represents mild depression, where symptoms are present but typically do not cause significant impairment in daily functioning. Individuals scoring 20 to 28 fall into the category of moderate depression, where symptoms are more pronounced and begin to interfere with work, social activities, and general daily life. Scores between 29 and 63 indicate severe depression, characterized by significant distress and functional impairment, often accompanied by symptoms such as hopelessness, pervasive sadness, and, in some cases, suicidal thoughts.

The WHODAS 2.0 records functional ability and disability caused by a disease. The domains are based on the conceptual framework of the WHO's International Classification of Functioning Disability and Health (ICF), which has been the international standard since 2001. The WHODAS 2.0 assesses health status on the basis of 36 questions from six different domains: cognition, understanding and communication, mobility, self-care, social interaction and social participation. Each of the 36 answers is assigned a predefined score: “None”—1, “Low”—2, “Moderate”—3, “Strong”—4 and “Very strong/not possible”—5. All the points are then added together to obtain a total score that reflects a patient's state of health. The total score represents the overall state of health in relation to the six health areas. The higher the scores are, the greater the disease-related burden [35–42].

sec.title: Statistics
sec.p: Unless otherwise stated, the percentage frequency (%) is used to describe categorical variables. The arithmetic mean, median, and standard deviation are used to represent continuous variables. The statistics are based on nonmissing data. The statistical analyses were carried out via SPSS 27.

sec.title: Results
sec.p:
A total of 207 patients with CHs were included in the analysis. The mean age was 48.16 ± 13.60 years, with a range between 18 and 77 years. Among the admitted patients, 62.3% were men, and 37.7% were women, corresponding to a male:female ratio of 1.6:1. Among the 207 patients with CHs analyzed, the majority were long-term sufferers. In fact, 71.5% of the patients reported experiencing pain for over 5 years (Fig. 1a).Fig. 1
a Frequency distribution of the duration of disease (%): Among the 207 patients with cluster headaches analyzed, the majority were long-term sufferers, with 71.5% reporting pain lasting more than 5 years. b Frequency distribution of the intensity of headaches (%). Almost all patients (98.6%) reported the pain as being severe to very severe (verbal rating scale: no, very weak, weak, medium, strong, very strong pain intensity). c Frequency distribution of attacks/day. At admission, 21.8% of the patients reported experiencing three attacks per day, with most experiencing one to six daily attacks. d Frequency distribution of cluster headaches with persistent pain. Approximately 31.4% of the patients with cluster headaches reported persistent pain in the affected area

A total of 61.8% of patients with CHs reported no remission phases lasting at least 3 months, indicating that they had chronic CHs. The remaining 38.2% of the patients were classified as having episodic CHs.

The duration of attacks ranged from 15 to 180 min for 98.1% of the patients, with only 1.9% experiencing attacks as long as 180 min. No patient reported attack durations shorter than 15 min. According to the ICHD-3 criteria, CH attacks may be less severe and/or shorter or longer in duration during part, but less than half, of the active time course. Accordingly, these patients also met the ICHD-3 criteria.

Pain was localized to the right periorbital side in 52% of the patients, to the left periorbital side in 46% of the patients, and alternated between sides in 2% of the patients. The pain location changed sides between cluster bouts in 2% of the patients. Nearly all patients (98.6%) described the pain intensity as severe to very severe (Fig. 1b).

In terms of attack frequency, the most common pattern at the time of the admission decision was three attacks per day, reported by 21.8% of the patients. The majority experienced between one and six attacks daily (Fig. 1c). There were no patients who experienced less than one attack per day in the study. Approximately 31.4% of the patients with CHs reported experiencing persistent pain in the affected area (Fig. 1d).

Among the individuals analyzed, 50.2% identified a specific time of day when their cluster attacks typically occurred, with multiple responses allowed. Of these patients, 79.3% reported that the attacks occurred predominantly between 9:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. (Fig. 2a). The other 49.8% of the patients did not report a typical diurnal course.Fig. 2
a Frequency distribution of the occurrence of attacks in relation to the time of day (%). Among the 50.2% of patients reporting specific attack times, 79.3% reported attacks primarily between 9:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. b Frequency distribution of pain type (%) (multiple answers possible). Pain was most often described as stabbing (80.2%), drilling (50.2%), flashing (43.5%), pulsating (42%), or burning (37.7%). c Frequency distribution of accompanying symptoms (%) (multiple answers possible). A total of 61.2% of the patients reported accompanying symptoms, most commonly sleep disturbances (93.2%), restlessness (85.3%), tearing (82.1%), agitation (75.8%), eye redness (70.5%), nasal congestion (62.8%), light sensitivity (51.2%), and sweating (51.2%). d Frequency distribution of the Beck Depression Inventory II (DBI-II) score(%). According to the Beck Depression Inventory, 79.3% of the patients with cluster headaches presented symptoms of depression: 23.7% had mild, 27.1% had moderate, and 28.5% had severe symptoms
The type of pain was most described as stabbing (80.2%), drilling (50.2%), flashing (43.5%), pulsating (42%), or burning (37.7%) (Fig. 2b).

Additionally, 61.2% of the patients reported symptoms accompanying their pain (Fig. 2c). The most frequently reported symptoms included sleep disturbances (93.2%), restlessness (85.3%), tearing (82.1%), agitation (75.8%), eye redness (70.5%), nasal congestion (62.8%), light sensitivity (51.2%), and sweating (51.2%).

Symptoms were reported to worsen under specific conditions: 43% of the patients linked symptom aggravation to seasonal changes, 37.7% linked it to weather conditions, 33.3% linked it to the use of stimulants, 31.9% linked it to emotional stress, and 30.9% linked it to uncomfortable head or body posture (Table 1).Table 1
Variables that worsen symptoms of the disease and the use of psychoactive substances
Frequency (%)
Variables that worsen symptoms
Season spring/autumn43.0
Weather37.7
Stimulants33.3
Mental stress31.9
Uncomfortable head or body posture30.9
Use of psychoactive substances
Alcohol30.4
Nicotine56.5
Caffeine81.6
Other6.8

With respect to the use of psychoactive substances, 30.4% of the patients reported regular alcohol consumption, 56.5% smoked cigarettes, 81.6% consumed caffeine regularly, and 6.8% used other drugs (Table 1).

The MIDAS score, which measures headache-related disability, was grade 4 (severe disability) in 94.7% of the patients (195 out of 207). As the MIDAS score measures disability over a period of 3 months, the score for 1.5% of the patients with a disease duration of less than 3 months underestimates the severity of disability.

Furthermore, 79.3% of patients with CHs presented symptoms consistent with depression on the basis of the BDI. Among these patients, 23.7% were categorized as having mild depression, 27.1% were categorized as having moderate depression, and 28.5% were categorized as having severe depression (Fig. 2d).

The analysis of the WHODAS 2.0 revealed that 92.7% of the patients with CHs experienced severe limitations in their health and functionality, leading to significant impairment. On average, the patients reported having health problems 23 out of 30 days per month. Owing to these issues, they were unable to perform activities on 13 days, and they had to reduce their daily tasks or work on 20 out of 30 days (Fig. 3a).Fig. 3
a Frequency distribution of the WHODAS-2 characteristics (%). According to WHODAS 2.0, 92.7% of the patients with cluster headaches faced severe health and functional limitations, with problems reported 23 days per month, 13 days of total inactivity reported, and 20 days of reduced activity reported. b Frequency distribution of accompanying psychological symptoms (%). Psychological symptoms were common, with 91.2% of the patients reporting a lack of energy, 90.8% reporting fatigue, 89.8% reporting concentration issues, 88.1% reporting exhaustion, 87.7% reporting reduced social activities, 86.8% reporting limited daily activities, 85% reporting rumination, 84.9% reporting irritability, and 81% reporting decreased performance. The data were recorded using the Kiel Headache Questionnaire. c Frequency distribution of suicidal ideation (%). Notably, 40.5% of the patients reported occasional suicidal ideation, 7.6% experienced regular suicidal ideation, and 1.8% expressed the intent to commit suicide if possible. The data were recorded using the Kiel Headache Questionnaire. d Frequency distribution of hospital admissions in Germany in 2022 due to ICD-10 diagnosis G44.0 depending on age [20]

Figure 3b illustrates the prevalence of additional psychologically distressing symptoms. A lack of energy affected 91.2% of the patients, whereas 90.8% reported fatigue, 89.8% reported concentration difficulties, and 88.1% reported exhaustion. A total of 87.7% of the patients reduced their social activities, and 86.8% reported limitations in their daily activities. Additionally, 85% of the patients experienced rumination, 84.9% experienced irritability, and 81% experienced a decline in performance.

Other reported symptoms included gloomy thoughts (76.3%), tension at work or in the family (66.5%), struggles with pain (66%), and anxiety (65.5%). The inability to work and frequent medical visits were reported by 63.6% of the patients, while irritability (63.1%), helplessness (55.9%), sensitivity (53.4%), depressed mood (52%), and restlessness (50.1%) were also common. Increased pain progression was noted by 42.3% of the patients, and protective behavior was noted by 37%.

Notably, 40.5% of the surveyed patients reported occasional suicidal ideation, 7.6% had regular suicidal ideation, and 1.8% expressed a willingness to commit suicide if they were given the opportunity (Fig. 3c).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: In this retrospective analysis, the data of patients who were admitted to a tertiary headache center in 2018, 2019, and 2020 with a principal diagnosis of CHs were recorded. The patients met the general admission criteria for inpatient multimodal pain therapy according to the procedure code OPS 8–918 [21]. The analysis revealed a pronounced symptom complex in patients with CHs that went far beyond the purely diagnostic criteria [1]. Most patients had a chronic, long-term disease course of more than 5 years. The gender ratio of men:women was 1.6:1, which is significantly lower than that of the overall population of those affected [4, 7, 43–47]. Almost all patients with CHs experience attacks with severe to very severe pain intensity with a high daily frequency. Approximately 80% of patients with CHs have attacks between 9:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m., with a particularly high incidence of approximately one-third between 0 a.m. and 3 a.m. This usually results in severe sleep disorders with exhaustion, a lack of energy and an inability to work. A total of 31.4% of patients have a permanent headache in the cluster area, which contributes to further disability. Persisting pain in the cluster area has also been described in other detailed analyses [48] but has not yet been included in the ICHD criteria [1].

In addition to the criteria specified in the ICHD-3 [1], affected individuals have partially severe accompanying psychological symptoms and psychosocial impacts of CHs. Exhaustion, fatigue, concentration difficulties and a lack of energy are the most common symptoms. Most individuals with CHs are no longer able to carry out social activities or everyday activities. They experience rumination, irritability, reduced performance, protective behavior, anxiety, increased pain progression, and gloomy thoughts. Patients often experience tension at work or in the family, the inability to work and frequent visits to the doctor.

Complex psychological effects have also been reported in other studies, particularly when patients with CHs receive a delayed diagnosis [4, 15, 16]. This can result in frequent changes in doctors, treatments that are not indicated, and increases in suffering and disease progression. The increasing knowledge and application of the ICHD-3 criteria in healthcare has led to a reduction in diagnostic delays in recent decades [16]. However, atypical features of CHs and multiple diagnoses, such as the combination of CHs with migraine or medication overuse headache, can lead to delays in diagnosis or incorrect treatment [16]. Our data highlight the great significance of the psychological impact of CHs in the family, social and professional spheres. The treatment of CHs should therefore focus not only on CH therapy and prevention but also on the psychological impact of the disorder [10, 12, 18]. This could lead to hospital admissions being avoided. Multidisciplinary treatment involving psychiatric and psychological disciplines should also be considered at an early stage in the outpatient sector [17, 49].

The stressful effects of CHs are particularly evident in the high frequency of suicidal ideation. Over 40% of the patients surveyed had suicidal ideation at times, and over 7% experienced suicidal ideation regularly; 1.8% of the patients would commit suicide if they had the opportunity. Accordingly, almost 80% of people with CHs reported symptoms attributable to depression in the BDI. This high frequency of suicidal ideation confirms the findings of other studies [49–51]. Demoralization, helplessness, hopelessness, and subjective incompetence to control pain are important [50]. Therefore, patients should be screened for both suicidal ideation and demoralization.

The high burden of treatment-refractory CHs was also reflected in the MIDAS score (grade 4), corresponding to very severe disability, for almost all those affected. MIDAS was developed to record the disability caused by migraine. However, it can also be used as a measure of disability from other headaches such as CHs. This was also evident in the WHODAS 2.0 analysis, in which over 92% of patients with CHs had severely restricted health and functional ability and a high degree of impairment. The individual burden of CH is very high. The results support the need to develop further treatment options. Patients with CHs should be screened in an outpatient setting via appropriate scales [52]. Psychosocial counseling involving the family, partner and workplace during treatment can help reduce the level of suffering and increase awareness and understanding.

The admitted patients were usually registered by specialized neurologists or pain therapists. The patients were treated in the outpatient area in accordance with the guidelines [53]. Accordingly, the reasons for admission were not the lack of individual measures, such as attack therapy, prevention, or invasive measures such as GON blocks. In contrast, these options have generally been implemented several times without sufficient effects. This led to the development of the symptom complex described in the procedure code OPS 8–918 as an admission criterion [21].

The data from this study are relevant from a clinical perspective. They showed that CHs can be an extremely serious condition for affected individuals and can have serious consequences if only unimodal medication is used. CHs affect almost all areas of professional, social, and family life. They cause severe psychological symptoms such as depression, social withdrawal, anxiety, and suicidal behavior. Psychosocial factors must therefore be given close attention in the care of patients with CHs [8, 10–12, 18, 54–56]. In addition to specific medications for the acute treatment and prevention of CHs, the therapeutic approach should also include education, psychotherapeutic measures and the involvement of relatives. This should become as normal as it is for other serious illnesses, such as cancer. CHs can lead to considerable emotional stress, such as anxiety, depression, grief, and hopelessness. Patients need help to address the diagnosis, process emotions, and develop coping strategies. Emotional stability must be promoted, and coping with physical symptoms such as pain must become easier. Patients must be motivated to continue their medical treatment consistently and to persevere through difficult therapies. Relatives are often also under psychological strain. Psychologists can help relatives cope better with the situation and support patients. Psychological interventions can reduce the risk of anxiety disorders, depression and posttraumatic stress disorders or treat such disorders in a targeted manner [19].

The epidemiology of CHs has been analyzed in several population-based studies. The incidence characteristics are summarized as follows [57]. The 12-month incidence of CHs is approximately 0.1–0.2%. This means that approximately 80,000–160,000 people are affected by CHs in Germany [43, 44, 58–60]. Men experience CHs more frequently than women do, with a ratio of approximately 3.5:1 [4, 7, 43–47]. The onset of the disease typically occurs around the age of 30 years. However, attacks can occur as early as childhood [57]. First-degree relatives of affected individuals have an 18-fold increased risk of also developing CHs. For second-degree relatives, the risk is up to three times greater [57]. Figure 3d shows the frequency distribution of patients treated as inpatients in Germany in 2021 with the main diagnosis of ICD-10 code G44.0 according to data from the German Federal Statistical Office (Destatis) [20]. A total of 1049 men and 527 women were hospitalized nationwide. The data collected in this study show the severity of the disease and the variety of symptoms in this patient group for the first time.

This study has several limitations. By retrospectively analyzing patients who were admitted for inpatient treatment, patients with particularly severe disease were included in the study. The resulting clinical headache phenotype therefore represents particularly severe forms. These findings cannot be generalized to the overall group of patients with CHs. MIDAS was originally developed for the assessment of migraine disability, so the transfer of grades for cluster headache may not be discriminative. The analyses are based on the answers given in the questionnaires. The patients indicated their phenotype and the effects of the pain from memory. Therefore, recall bias may influence the data. However, in view of the very long course of CHs, it can be assumed that the influence of such a bias is small.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: This study revealed a pronounced symptom complex in patients with CHs who were admitted for inpatient treatment, which extended far beyond the purely diagnostic criteria. Most patients had a chronic, long-term disease course. The attacks occurred with a strong to very strong intensity of pain with a high daily frequency. Those affected experienced particularly severe suffering caused by the accompanying psychological symptoms and the psychosocial impact of CHs. The severe and stressful complications of CHs were particularly evident in the high frequency of suicidal ideation in more than 40% of the patients analyzed. Psychosocial factors must therefore be given close attention in the care of patients with CHs. In addition to specific medications for the acute treatment and prevention of CHs, the therapeutic approach should also include education, psychotherapeutic measures. and the involvement of relatives. This should become as normal as it is for other serious illnesses.

ack.title: Acknowledgements
ack.p: We thank the participants of the study. We also thank the Kiel Migraine and Headache Centre, Germany, for permission to use patient data consisting of the scales and questionnaires used.

notes.title: Author Contributions
notes.p: Carl Göbel contributed to the design and conceptualization of the study, performed the statistical analysis, interpreted the results, and wrote the first draft of the manuscript. Axel Heinze, Katja Heinze-Kuhn, and Anna Cirkel contributed to the interpretation and analysis of the data. Britta Koch contributed to data collection, as well as the interpretation and analysis of the results. Hartmut Göbel contributed to the design and conceptualization of the study and was involved in co-writing the manuscript. All authors reviewed and approved the final version of the manuscript.

notes.title: Funding
notes.p: No funding or sponsorship was received for this study or publication of this article.

notes.title: Data Availability
notes.p: The datasets generated during and/or analyzed during the current study are available from the corresponding author upon reasonable request.

notes.title: Conflict of Interest
notes.p: The authors Carl H. Göbel, Britta Koch, Katja Heinze-Kuhn, Axel Heinze, and Hartmut Göbel declare that they have no financial conflicts of interest or competing interests.

notes.title: Ethical Approval
notes.p: All patients included in this study provided written informed consent for the collection and analysis of their data. The study was conducted in accordance with the principles of the Declaration of Helsinki and approved by the ethics committee of the University of Kiel (D 626/20). Patient confidentiality and data protection were ensured throughout the study, and all data were anonymized prior to analysis.
